metadata.description: KNGF (Royal Dutch Society for Physical Therapy) Clinical Practice Guidelines - Key Decision Points
metadata.purpose: Quick reference for CRISP coaching on evidence-based physiotherapy decision-making
source_documents: KNGF Guideline on Low Back Pain (2013, updated 2017)
KNGF Guideline on Hip and Knee Osteoarthritis (2018)
SNN Basisprotocol Rotator Cuff Repair (Samenwerkingsverband Nazorg Netwerk)
JOSPT Clinical Practice Guideline: Rotator Cuff Tendinopathy 2025
metadata.usage_note: These are key decision points extracted from full guidelines. Students should read complete guidelines for comprehensive understanding. Note: No dedicated KNGF guideline exists for shoulder pathology — NHG M08 and NOV/FMS SAPS serve as primary Dutch references.

low_back_pain.guideline_title: KNGF Guideline on Low Back Pain
low_back_pain.scope: Adults with non-specific low back pain with or without leg symptoms

red_flags: Cauda equina syndrome symptoms (urinary retention, fecal incontinence, saddle anesthesia)
step_1_red_flag_screening.action_if_present: Consider urgent referral for medical evaluation and possible imaging
step_1_red_flag_screening.coaching_prompt: What red flags did you screen for? What would you do if any were present?

step_2_yellow_flag_screening.purpose: Identify psychosocial risk factors for chronicity
yellow_flags: Expectation that passive treatments will help
step_2_yellow_flag_screening.action_if_present: Address through education, cognitive-behavioral approaches, graded activity
step_2_yellow_flag_screening.coaching_prompt: What yellow flags did you identify? How might these affect prognosis and your treatment approach?

step_3_specific_vs_nonspecific.specific_lbp: Identifiable pathoanatomical cause (fracture, infection, tumor, cauda equina, radiculopathy)
step_3_specific_vs_nonspecific.nonspecific_lbp: No specific pathoanatomical diagnosis possible (~90% of LBP)
step_3_specific_vs_nonspecific.clinical_note: Most patients have non-specific LBP. Treatment focuses on function, not finding specific tissue pathology.
step_3_specific_vs_nonspecific.coaching_prompt: Is this specific or non-specific LBP? What evidence supports your classification?

imaging_decision.indication: Only if red flags present or to confirm suspected specific pathology
imaging_decision.rationale: Imaging findings (disc degeneration, bulging) are common in asymptomatic individuals and may increase patient worry
imaging_decision.coaching_prompt: Would you recommend imaging for this patient? What does the guideline say about routine imaging?

recommended.description: Reassurance, stay active, hurt ≠ harm, favorable prognosis
recommended.coaching_prompt: What key messages would you give this patient about their back pain?

recommended.description: Any type of exercise (aerobic, strengthening, stretching, motor control)
recommended.coaching_prompt: What type of exercise would you choose for this patient and why?

recommended.description: Progressive increase in activity levels despite pain
recommended.coaching_prompt: How would you implement graded activity with this patient?

recommended.evidence: Moderate-strong for chronic LBP with psychological factors
recommended.coaching_prompt: What behavioral approaches would you incorporate?

conditionally_recommended.condition: Only as adjunct to exercise in acute/subacute phase
conditionally_recommended.coaching_prompt: Under what conditions might manual therapy be appropriate?

not_recommended.rationale: No evidence of benefit, may promote passive coping

treatment_recommendations.coaching_prompt: Does your intervention plan align with KNGF recommendations? What is the evidence level for your chosen interventions?

prognosis.coaching_prompt: What is the expected prognosis for this patient? What factors influence your prediction?

neck_pain.scope: Adults with non-specific neck pain, WAD grades I-II, cervicogenic headache

classification.grade_2_wad: Neck complaints + musculoskeletal signs (decreased ROM, point tenderness)
classification.grade_3_wad: Neck complaints + neurological signs (decreased reflexes, weakness, sensory deficits)

red_flags: Signs of myelopathy (gait disturbance, bilateral symptoms, bladder/bowel)
Signs of vertebral artery insufficiency (dizziness, diplopia, drop attacks, dysarthria, dysphagia, nystagmus)
Malignancy (unexplained weight loss, history of cancer)
Inflammatory conditions (morning stiffness >1 hour, multiple joint involvement)
red_flag_screening.coaching_prompt: What red flags specific to neck pain did you assess?

prognostic_screening.coaching_prompt: What prognostic factors are present that might influence recovery?

recommended.description: Strengthening, endurance, motor control exercises for neck/shoulder
Combination of exercise + manual therapy + education

conditionally_recommended.condition: As part of multimodal approach, not alone

treatment_recommendations.coaching_prompt: What multimodal approach would you implement for this neck pain patient?

hip_knee_osteoarthritis.guideline_title: KNGF Guideline on Hip and Knee Osteoarthritis
hip_knee_osteoarthritis.scope: Adults with symptomatic hip or knee osteoarthritis

diagnosis.coaching_prompt: Can you diagnose OA clinically or is imaging required?

core_interventions.description: Disease information, weight management, activity pacing

adjunctive_interventions.condition: Short-term adjunct to exercise for hip OA
When needed for pain relief and safety

treatment_principles.coaching_prompt: What are the core interventions every OA patient should receive?

strengthening.coaching_prompt: How would you progress strengthening exercises for this OA patient?

aerobic.coaching_prompt: What aerobic exercise options would you discuss with a patient who has knee OA?

pain_during_exercise.acceptable: Mild-moderate pain during/after exercise is acceptable
pain_during_exercise.flare_management: Temporary activity modification, not complete rest
pain_during_exercise.coaching_prompt: The patient is worried about exercising because of pain. What would you tell them?

indications: Severe pain and disability despite optimal conservative management (6+ months)
Significant impact on quality of life
Radiographic evidence of OA (for surgical planning, not diagnosis)
referral_for_surgery.coaching_prompt: When would you consider referring this OA patient for surgical consultation?

shoulder_complaints.guideline_note: No dedicated KNGF guideline exists for shoulder complaints. The following is synthesized from NHG M08, NOV/FMS SAPS 2025, SNN RC Repair Protocol, and JOSPT 2025 CPG.

nhg_m08.title: NHG-Standaard Schouderklachten M08
nhg_m08.scope: Primary care assessment and management of shoulder complaints

nov_fms_saps_2025.title: NOV/FMS Richtlijn Subacromiale Pijn Syndrome (SAPS)
nov_fms_saps_2025.scope: Specialist-level diagnosis and management of subacromial pain syndrome

snn_rc_repair.title: SNN Basisprotocol Rotator Cuff Repair
snn_rc_repair.scope: Post-operative rehabilitation protocol for rotator cuff repair

jospt_rc_tendinopathy_2025.title: JOSPT Clinical Practice Guideline: Rotator Cuff Tendinopathy
jospt_rc_tendinopathy_2025.scope: Conservative management of rotator cuff tendinopathy

step_1_red_flag_screening.purpose: Exclude serious pathology requiring urgent referral
red_flags: Acute traumatic onset with significant weakness (suspect acute full-thickness tear)
Suspected fracture or dislocation (trauma mechanism, deformity)
Suspected malignancy (unexplained weight loss, history of cancer, constant unrelenting pain)
Acute severe pain with inability to move shoulder (suspect septic arthritis)
Progressive neurological deficit (brachial plexopathy, cervical radiculopathy)
step_1_red_flag_screening.action_if_present: Urgent referral for medical evaluation and imaging
step_1_red_flag_screening.coaching_prompt: What red flags did you screen for in this shoulder presentation? How do shoulder red flags differ from lumbar red flags?

step_2_yellow_flag_screening.purpose: Identify psychosocial risk factors for chronicity
yellow_flags: Passive coping strategies (expecting injection/surgery to fix it)
Previous negative healthcare experiences with shoulder
step_2_yellow_flag_screening.action_if_present: Integrate psychosocial management into exercise-based treatment. Consider referral if severe.
step_2_yellow_flag_screening.coaching_prompt: What yellow flags did you identify? How might these affect prognosis and your treatment approach for this shoulder patient?

step_3_diagnostic_approach_2025.key_change: NOV/FMS SAPS 2025 dismantles traditional orthopaedic test clusters
step_3_diagnostic_approach_2025.recommended_approach: Single high-accuracy test strategy rather than test batteries
step_3_diagnostic_approach_2025.rule_in_test: Empty Can Test (Jobe's) — high specificity for RC involvement
step_3_diagnostic_approach_2025.rule_out_test: Hawkins-Kennedy Test — high sensitivity, negative effectively excludes subacromial involvement
step_3_diagnostic_approach_2025.symptom_modification_tests: New 2025 concept — identify modifiable factors (scapular assistance, thoracic extension, humeral head relocation)
step_3_diagnostic_approach_2025.coaching_prompt: You performed 6 special tests for this shoulder. What does the 2025 NOV guideline say about test clusters? Which single test would most change your reasoning?

imaging_decision.jospt_2025_rule: 12-week imaging prohibition before conservative management failure is established
not_indicated: Routine assessment before 12 weeks of conservative management
Patient or referrer request without clinical indication
indicated: Red flags present (fracture, dislocation, infection, malignancy)
Acute traumatic onset with significant weakness (suspect acute full-thickness tear)
Failure of ≥12 weeks adequate conservative management
imaging_decision.rationale: Structural findings poorly correlate with symptoms. Asymptomatic RC tears are common and increase with age. Early imaging may reinforce biomedical beliefs.
imaging_decision.coaching_prompt: The patient wants an MRI at 4 weeks. What does the 2025 evidence say? How would you explain this to the patient without dismissing their concerns?

recommended.description: Explain tendinopathy (not 'inflammation'), favorable prognosis with active management, hurt ≠ harm, activity modification not cessation
recommended.coaching_prompt: What key messages would you give this shoulder patient about their condition?

recommended.description: Isometric → isotonic → eccentric → heavy slow resistance → functional loading
recommended.coaching_prompt: What loading phase is appropriate for this patient's tendon irritability? How would you progress?

recommended.description: Address scapular dyskinesis contributing to subacromial narrowing. Lower trapezius, serratus anterior focus.
recommended.coaching_prompt: Did you assess scapular contribution to symptoms? What did the scapular assistance test show?

recommended.description: Screen and address fear-avoidance, catastrophizing, low recovery expectations
recommended.evidence: Strong (extrapolated from MSK evidence, supported by JOSPT 2025)
recommended.coaching_prompt: What psychosocial factors are influencing this patient's presentation?

conditionally_recommended.condition: Only as adjunct to exercise, not standalone
NOT first-line. Only when pain prevents participation in exercise program
conditionally_recommended.caution: May suppress collagen synthesis. Maximum 3 injections.

not_recommended.rationale: Only for calcific tendinopathy. NOT for non-calcific RC tendinopathy.
Not first-line. Insufficient evidence for routine use.
Must NOT be first-line for shoulder pain.

treatment_recommendations.coaching_prompt: Does your intervention plan align with 2025 shoulder guidelines? What is the evidence level for your chosen interventions?

immobilization_tension.nov_2025: 3 weeks for isolated supraspinatus, small-to-medium tear, good tissue quality
immobilization_tension.snn_baseline: 6 weeks as standard (4 weeks progressive, 8-10 weeks conservative variant)
immobilization_tension.clinical_reasoning_note: This is a genuine clinical tension — both positions are evidence-informed. Tear size is the key moderator.
immobilization_tension.coaching_prompt: The surgeon prescribed 6 weeks in a sling. The NOV 2025 guideline suggests 3 weeks may suffice for this tear profile. How do you navigate this?

postoperative_rc_repair.coaching_prompt: What phase is this patient in? What criteria must be met before progressing?

prognosis.rc_tendinopathy: Good with consistent conservative management (8-12 weeks). 60-80% of patients improve significantly with exercise therapy alone.
prognosis.post_rc_repair: Full recovery typically 6-9 months. Return to overhead sport/heavy work may take 9-12 months.
poor_prognostic_factors: Significant yellow flags (high TSK, high PCS)
Diabetes mellitus (increases stiffness risk, delays healing)
Duration of symptoms >6 months before treatment
Significant fatty infiltration of RC muscles
prognosis.coaching_prompt: What is the expected prognosis for this patient? What factors are working for and against a good outcome?

student_recommends_imaging_without_indic.scenario: Student wants to order MRI for non-specific LBP without red flags
student_recommends_imaging_without_indic.coaching_response: What does the KNGF guideline say about imaging for non-specific LBP? What might be the unintended consequences of imaging for this patient?

student_focuses_only_on_biomedical_facto.scenario: Student ignores yellow flags and plans only manual therapy
student_focuses_only_on_biomedical_facto.coaching_response: You've addressed the physical impairments. What psychosocial factors might be influencing this patient's presentation? How do these affect your treatment plan?

student_recommends_passive_treatment_alo.scenario: Student prescribes ultrasound and massage without active exercise
student_recommends_passive_treatment_alo.coaching_response: What does the evidence say about passive modalities for this condition? How might passive-only treatment affect the patient's beliefs about their recovery?

student_advises_rest_and_activity_avoida.scenario: Student tells patient to rest and avoid activities until pain-free
student_advises_rest_and_activity_avoida.coaching_response: What does the guideline recommend about activity levels? How might prolonged rest affect this patient's recovery?

student_sets_impairment_focused_goals.scenario: Student sets goal 'increase hip flexion ROM to 120 degrees'
student_sets_impairment_focused_goals.coaching_response: This goal focuses on an impairment. What functional activity does the patient want to achieve? How would you reframe this as an activity-level goal?

low_back_pain: Your back is strong - it's designed to move
Pain doesn't mean damage - hurt doesn't always equal harm
Staying active helps recovery - bed rest delays it
Most back pain improves within 6 weeks
X-rays and MRIs are rarely needed and often show 'normal aging' changes that worry people unnecessarily
Exercise is medicine for your back
neck_pain: Most neck pain is not serious and recovers well
Gentle movement helps - collars can delay recovery
Stress and tension contribute to neck pain - addressing these helps
Regular exercise and good posture support recovery
osteoarthritis: Arthritis can be managed - it doesn't mean the end of activity
Exercise is the most effective treatment - it won't wear out your joints
Some pain during exercise is normal and acceptable
Losing weight (if overweight) significantly reduces joint stress
You can still do activities you enjoy with some modifications
shoulder_tendinopathy: Your tendon is not torn or broken - it is sensitized and needs graduated loading
Complete rest makes tendons weaker - controlled loading makes them stronger
Pain during exercise is acceptable if it settles within 24 hours
Recovery takes time (8-12 weeks minimum) but the prognosis is good with consistent exercise
An MRI is usually not needed and often shows changes that are normal for your age
You don't need to stop all activities - modify them so you can keep moving
shoulder_post_operative: The repair needs protection initially, but movement will start sooner than you might expect
Stiffness is a common challenge after surgery - gentle, consistent ROM work is essential
Strengthening will begin when the tendon has healed enough - your physiotherapist will guide the timing
Full recovery takes 6-9 months - this is frustrating but the tendon needs time to remodel
Pain does not mean the repair has failed - discuss any concerns with your physiotherapist
